headline: Lieberman: McCain wanted bipartisan ticket to make impact
subHeadline: Former Democratic Senator Joe Lieberman joins 'Your World' with insight into his unique friendship with the Republican senator.

utterances.speaker: NEIL CAVUTO, HOST
utterances.sentences: All right, an excerpt from John McCain's latest book read by John McCain himself, "The Restless Wave: Good Times, Just Causes, Great Fights, and Other Appreciations."  It's caused hackles on all sides of the political fence, or both sides of the political fence. It's gotten some conservatives very, very upset. It's gotten some liberals just very, very perplexed. So, obviously, it's doing its job, in true to form of John McCain.  With me now is Senator Joe Lieberman, a good friend of John McCain. In fact, you recently visited him, right, senator?

utterances.speaker: SEN. JOSEPH LIEBERMAN, FORMER U.S. SENATOR
utterances.sentences: I did, Neil. I was there a week ago Friday.   At that point, he was at the Mayo Clinic in Scottsdale. And he was OK, really. We had a good conversation. We told some really tired old jokes to each other.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You, tired old jokes?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: But we laughed at each other. A little known fact about McCain, if you mentioned the name Henny Youngman, which is not known too much anymore, a stand-up comedian...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: ... he will give you at least a dozen quick Henny Youngman one-liners.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And that's how it's done.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Anyway, thank God he was OK then. But really, as he said to me, the thing he most wanted was to get out of the hospital.  Following Monday, he did. He's back on the family -- at the family place outside Sedona, Arizona, which he loves. So, hopefully, he's getting better every day.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Of course, for those who don't know, he`s battling a brain tumor, a very advanced brain tumor, with great courage. It's never easy, no matter what side of the political fence you're on.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But what has caused a great sort of a dust-up in this recollection and his book is his musing back over his own life. And he freely admits a lot of mistakes he made.  And it`s a very kind of a humbling journey through his raucous 81-plus years on this planet. And among them is his 2008 selection when he was the party's presidential nominee, picking Sarah Palin, for whom he has high praise and thinks a great deal of her.   But he thought the better gut call would have been for him to select you. He wanted to. He said it was a reach-over, a crossover. But party consultants felt that maybe, given your pro-choice views and others and your association with that other party, would have been a bad move. What did you think of that?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I'll tell you, in 2008, when John McCain said he wanted to vet me for vice president on his ticket, I said, are you kidding me? I really did. And he said, no, I`m serious.  So, I said, you know, you don't -- I was reelected as an independent, but maybe I have to remind you, my dear friend, I'm a Democrat still. He said, that`s the point.  And I think he felt at that moment, when we were already getting frozen into rigid partisanship and a lot of things that should have been done were not being done, that he could make a big statement by having a bipartisan ticket. It really says an awful lot about him. And I was surprised when he wrote what he did in the book. And I`m honored by it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But he did approach you? He did approach you? Because I remember those overtures. He did actually approach you and you -- did you both kick it around?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I said, look, I honestly don`t see how you can do this. But if you want to vet me -- meaning he put me through the process of being investigated, my background and...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But you had already been vetted in the past.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Several times.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, once before.   So, it was serious. But, in the end, as he says in the book, the people, his consultants convinced him that it wasn`t a good idea and he would divide the Republican Party. And that would also have an effect on him.  And I understood completely.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Did he get back to you and say, sorry, Joe, this is not going to work?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes, he did.  And I said, John, I understand. As I said to you at the beginning, I thought you were doing something that was so unusual that it was beyond what was possible. But he said, I wish we could have done it, but I can't do it. And it was also built on our friendship. We knew each other well. We trusted each other. We have some differences of opinion, particularly on some domestic policy issues, but on foreign policy, defense policy, almost 100 percent agreement.  And we traveled the world together and got to know each other really well.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Did he ask you to change your position, for example, on abortion?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: No. Never did.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Did he ask you to change your position on anything?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: No. Incidentally, I went through this in 2000. This shows what an unusual character I am, I guess, where there were positions that I had on things like school choice, for instance, where it was very different from Vice President Gore.   And the answer that I gave was the one that vice presidential candidates always give, which is that they will be true to what they believe is right. On the other hand, there's only one president. And, in other words, you have to support what the president wants. And if it becomes intolerable, then presumably you should leave the vice presidency. But that would take a lot.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Ultimately, he selected Sarah Palin.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: The new Alaska governor at the time. Did he share that with you that she would be his choice and what he made of that choice?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Believe it or not, not a lot.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: I probably -- when I get to sit down and read the book, I will probably learn about -- a lot more about all that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: When you met with him, did he say that that would be a big part of the book or that discussion of that whole episode?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: No. No.  But I did get to meet Sarah Palin for the first time at the Republican Convention in 2008. And I worked with her on foreign policy matters and was involved somewhat in preparation for the debate she had with Joe Biden. So, I mean, I got to know her and like her, truthfully.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: It's weird, Senator, how life goes full circle now, with Joe Biden and, of course with you, are friends.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And, of course, Joe Biden visited John McCain as well. So it just reminded me of a time maybe there was a collegial friendliness and all. What comes through loud and clear is that, whether John McCain admits this or not, you could argue that the selection of Sarah Palin ignited this sort of populist approach in the party, in the Republican Party in particular, that might have laid the groundwork for Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Maybe.  I mean, it took a lot of steps in between. So, I know John is really a gentleman and a civilized person. And I think he's grateful for all the effort that Sarah Palin gave during 2008. And I don't think he wants to say anything negative about her.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But just confirming what we had known, it's got to hurt her.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, maybe. Probably, to say that he wished he had chosen somebody else.  But it wasn't an easy call. And ,as I say, he took me on a ride I never expected. Hey, I never expected to run for vice president in the first place. To be considered twice, that was way beyond...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: That's pretty unusual.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Is America a great country or what?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Or what? And, also, we're getting the word that the senator doesn't want President Trump at his funeral. What do you think of that?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I have heard that. I don't -- honestly don't know whether that is true.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: When you met with him -- I don't want you to divulge private conversations, but I would be happy if you shared them.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Did you talk much about President Trump?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: No, not at all.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Really, at all?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, about President Trump?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, a little bit, but nothing about the funeral. Nothing about the funeral at all. And I hope to God...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: This relationship the two have, it seems so bitter and angry. Is it that way with the senator? When you say, I don't want to invite him to my funeral, that's pretty severe.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Incidentally, that rumor, which I think it is, sounded more personal.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You don't -- it's not true?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: I don't know that it's true. That sounded more personal than John McCain has been in his conversations with me about President Trump.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: In other words, he will disagree things that the president has done. But I don't feel that kind of personal hatred there at all.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But how do you think he would feel about the president entertaining dropping the deal with Iran, and that could come tomorrow?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: My guess is, he would be generally supportive of that, because he felt -- I know John McCain felt the original Iran nuclear deal was a bad deal for us, that we gave away too much, ended economic pressure on them, gave them $100 billion to spend to support terrorism and aggression in the Middle East, and we got from it a pause in their nuclear program, and not the ability to really fully inspect places in Iran.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And so you would concur with that?

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, totally. I was a critic of the Iran nuclear deal when it was signed. I have been encouraged by President Trump's statements about it. It's a bad deal, a mistake for the U.S. I`m very hopeful that, tomorrow, he will withdraw the United States. He has the authority not to slap sanctions back on immediately, or he could do it selectively. I mean, he could sanction the Bank of Iran in a way that would really hurt Iran. And let's look at these two countries. I know everybody is worried about the sky falling.  We're the strongest economy in the world. Iran is a tiny economy, and it's on a dive.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: OK. OK.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: They need this agreement much more than we do. So, if the president pulls out tomorrow, trust me, the Iranians are going to be brought back to the table.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Senator Lieberman, we shall see. Thank you, sir.

utterances.speaker: LIEBERMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Neil. Good to be with you. Copy: Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, Inc. Copyright CQ-2018 ASC Services II Media, LLC.
